column1: A stillbirth is when a baby dies in the womb during the last 20 weeks of pregnancy.

Some factors that can cause stillbirth are: - Birth defects - Abnormal chromosomes - Infection in the mother or fetus - Injuries - Chronic health conditions in the mother (diabetes, epilepsy, or high blood pressure) - Problems with the placenta that prevent the fetus from getting nourishment (such as placental detachment) - Sudden severe blood loss (hemorrhage) in the mother or fetus - Heart stoppage (cardiac arrest) in the mother or fetus - Umbilical cord problems Women at higher risk for stillbirth: - Are older than age 35 - Are obese - Are carrying multiple babies (twins or more) - Are African American - Have had a past stillbirth - Have high blood pressure or diabetes - Have other medical conditions (like lupus) - Take drugs
These may include internal exams (autopsy), x-rays, and genetic tests.
